docs.lead_paragraph: Heroin use, regarded for decades as the nation's most devastating drug problem, has stopped spreading in New York City and young people are spurning the drug, social scientists and drug-treatment centers say. On the street corners of Harlem, the Lower East Side and other inner-city neighborhoods around the country ravaged by the heroin epidemic of the late 1960's and early 70's, teen-agers - the people who determine future drug trends - are turning to cocaine as their drug of choice. ''People in their teens now are smoking cocaine, they are not doing heroin,'' said Mark Raskin, a spokesman for Daytop Village, a drug treatment center in New York City. ''Every generation wants to change. Our music changes. Our clothes change. Our drugs change.''

docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT draws young people to a flirtation with excess, risk, outrage and sometimes even evil? That question, in some form, inevitably faces virtually every parent of an adolescent. Now mental health experts are answering it as they examine the underlying psychological attractions of excess and try to establish what is part of normal growth and what is cause for worry. Throughout life there is a search for meaning and identity, but it is in late adolescence, roughly from the late teen-age years to the early 20's, that the search, and the experimentation that accompanies it, is fraught with particular peril. The dangers are many - unwanted pregnancy, drugs, crime, violence - and the consequences potentially fatal, as the much-publicized murder of Jennifer Dawn Levin demonstrates.
